p.seg: BIENNIAL REPORT of the Adjutant General of the State of Nebraska For 1919-1920

2 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL REPORT STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN December 31, 1920. From | The Adjutant General, Nebraska. To: | His Excellency, Samuel R. McKelvie, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. Subject: Biennial Report of 1919 and 1920. 1. In compliance with the requirements of Paragraph 3907, Section 9, Chapter 14, Article 1, Revised Statutes of Nebraska, the following bien - nial report for the calendar years 1919 and 1920 is respectfully submitted: HOME GUAKD Upon assuming the duties of the offiee of Adjutant General, March 4, 1919, it was learned that practically none of the National Guard had re - turned from the World War; that when they did return they would no long - er be available for State duties as a decision of the Judge Advocate Gen - eral, U. S. Army, had been rendered to this effect. No National Guard lad been reorganized after the call of July 15, 1917, but a special session of the Legislature had provided for the organization of Home Guard units and authorized County Commissioners to purchase arms and equip - ment for same. There were approximately 60,000 Home Guards organ - zed within the State, some being equipped and some not, and while the pirit of the Home Guard units was of the very best and the moral effect of such organizations improved conditions within the State, many of these organizations had disbanded on orders issued by the outgoing Governor, tut at the request of Governor Samuel R. McKelvie" the greater portion remained intact until such time as a sufficient number of the National iuard had been reorganized to make it safe for their disbandment. STATE RIFLES Upon information being received from a Committee of Omaha's rep - resentative citizens calling upon the Governor, that conditions were not lie best and that there was unusual activity among the anarchistic ele - men of the United States, it was deemed advisable to immediately organize uch a volunteer force as could be depended upon in case of an emergency nd a State military organization known as the Nebraska State Rifles was organized with one company at Nebraska City, one at Fairbury, one at Clay Center, and one in the western part of the State, at Alliance. These companies were each one hundred men companies and composed of all ex- Crvice men. Federal- equipment was drawn and issued to these organi - tions and it was considered an adequate organization to meet with any

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 5 emergency that might arise within the borders of our peace-loving State. These organizations were maintained until a sufficient number of the Na - tional Guard was reorganized to make it safe to relieve them from fur - ther duty. LEGISLATION The State Military Code was amended to conform to the Federal laws which was demanded by the United States Government before Nebraska could participate in appropriations allotted to the respective states for the support and maintenance of the National Guard. Liberal appropriation was made by the Legislature for the support of the National Guard and for the promotion of Rifle Practice, but the ap - propriation for Armory Rental would have been inadequate had it been possible to have perfected an immediate reorganization of the National Guard, which was made impossible by the State Legislature attaching a rider to the appropriation for the National Guard reading, "No part of the foregoing appropriation for the Nebraska National Guard shall be used except for the expenses in conducting the Adjutant General's office, un - til the National Congress has made an appropriation for the support of the National Guard of the United States". This was taken by this office to mean that the Legislature in their wisdom, desired that the State funds be not spent or the reorganization of the National Guard attempted un - til the Federal Government had adopted a military policy and made appropriations for the support thereof, and this was not accomplished until the Act of June 4, 1920, and therefore no concerted effort to re - organize the National Guard was made until after that time. PROPERTY There was but little Quartermaster, Ordnance, Medical and Signal property on hand in the State Arsenal at the time I assumed the du - ties of the office and upon the appointment and approval of a United States Property and Disbursing Officer, I had a physical count made of all property on hand in that the new officer would ba chargeable with only property actually on hand and that the old Property and Disburs - ing Officer would be enabled to settle his account with the War De - partment. A survey has been made of all property considered to be unserviceable and same has been condemned for destruction or to be returned to the War Department. Some antiquated property that was necessary to carry as serviceable has been returned to the Department in that we may draw new and up-to-date equipment u,pon the reorganization of the National Guard. The accountability of the State with the United States Government during the war, so far as this administration is concerned, has been cleared and all property accounts adjusted. The Arsenal has been cleaned out from top to bottom and made ready for new equipment.

4 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL HOUSE ROLL NO. 537 Conforming to House Roll No. 537, an effort was made to obtain from the Federal Government a copy of all records of the Selective Draft, but this was refused by the Adjutant General of the Army who in - formed us that no records would be returned to the States and that the State records would be kept in Washington. An effort was then made to obtain from the respective counties, lists of the Selective Draft nd those who volunteered and an alphabtical list was made, by counties, f most of the counties. These lists were incomplete as they lacked lome addresses and the counties seemed unable to give us the necessary ata to perfect them. About this time we were informed by the Adju - tant General of the Army that photostatic copies of registration and nduction lists would be forwarded from the War Department and upon eceipt of said notice, all effort and expense of obtaining further infor - mation from the respective counties was stopped. Upon receipt of the thotostatic copies and looking over of same, it was discovered that the nformation given in them would be incomplete and that such a record of the ex-service men as the Legislature had in mind could not bs per - fected, and then the united effort was made by the Adjutants General of the respective States to get Congress to pass a law compelling the Adjutant General of the Army to furnish individual records cf men serving from the respective States, which was accomplished and we are now receiving said individual service records which will give to each State an individual record of each soldier, sailor, marine and nurse who participated in the World War. An appropriation of $25,000.00 was made by the last session of the Legislature for the purpose of perfecting the above mentioned records and to furnish to the nearest relative of those making the Supreme Sacrifice a certificate of service with a gold star and to all others a cer - tificate of service without the gold star. These certificates are now on hand, the casual list made up and at this writing we are commencing to n-.ail same out as provided for in the Act. RIFLE RANGE The Rifle Range at Ashland, Nebraska, is much run down and badly in need of repair to place it in condition for range work. Arrangements had been made to have this Rifle Rang put in condition during the spring and summer of 1920, but owing to the fact that a military policy was not adopted by the National Congress until June 4, 1920, detailed information of which did not reach this office until the latter part of July, it was decided to let this work go over until the spring of 1921, and perfect our reorganization before expending the necessary amount of money in fixing up the Rifle Range for camp and range purposes. A Civilian Rifle Team under the leadership of Captain Lincoln Riley of Wisner, Nebraska, was sent to the National Rifle Competition at

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 5 Ep Perry, Ohio, in August 1920, and made a very creditable showing. h interest is being manifested in these Civilian Rifle Teams and a. ber of new teams have been organized during the fall and winter. REORGANIZATION OF THE NATIONAL GUARD As stated before, no concerted effort was made to reorganize the National Guard until after the; latter part of July 1920, when detailed information was received by this office from the War Department as to the military policy adopted by the Federal Government and appro - priations made for the carrying out of said policy. The allotment for Nebraska for the fiscal year ending July 1, 1921, is First regiment of Infantry, one Field Hospital company and one Sig - nal Company (Construction), of which Infantry companies have been or - ganized at Scottsbluff, Omaha, Hartington, Beatrice, Mitchell, Auburn, Falls City, and at this writing a company is ready for its first inspection at Hastings, another one at Omaha, with the organization of other units' in Lincoln, Grand Island, Columbus and Albion well under way. Nebraska's full allotment of National Guard units when the Act of June 4, 1920, is in full force and effect will be: It is anticipated that the allotment for July 1, 1921, will be one regi - ment of 155 mm. Howitzer and some of the auxiliary units. While this 155 mm. Howitzer regiment as such would be of no practical benefit to the State outside of preparing them for a National emergency, arrange - ments have been made whereby they will receive additional equipment from the Federal Governmnt for Infantry organizations and will be drilled as such in addition to their Artillery training, which will make them as valuable to the State, in case of local disorders, as would be an Infantry regiiment. bFull and complete equipment for each organization is furnished by- Federal Government and along this line I might add that the equip - it is of the latest design and model and everything from the skin out DIVISION TROOPS: CORPS TROOPS: 1 Infantry regiment 1 Medical regimental Hdqrs. 1 Sanitary Company 1 Ambulance battalion Hdqrs. 1 Ambulance company (motorized) 1 Hospital company 1 Medical Supply Section 1 Medical Laboratory 1 Veterinary Evacuation company 1 Division Trains (Q.M. C.) 1 Artillery regiment (155 mm Howitzer) 1 Air Service Observation Squad- ron 1 Signal company (construction) ARMY TROOPS: 1 Artillery Ammunition Train 1 Combat Engineer Regiment G. H. Q. RESERVE 1 Typographical battalion 1 Balloon group

6 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL is furnished the enlisted men. The equipment for each Infantry company costing approximatly $18,000,00., is furnished to the State, free of charge, by the Federal Government. OMAHA RIOT Sunday evening, September 28, 1919, there was a riot in Omaha and the State was called upon for assistance. No National Guard had been reorganized at this time and the Home Guard organizations of Omaha had disbanded. Every effort was made to get United States troops from Fort Crook and Fort Omaha to the scene of the trouble and it was through the efforts of the Governor's representatives that this was done, it being first necessary to take the matter up with the Secretary of War and then the Commanding General of the Central Department which caused much delay before the order for the troops to move was finally received. In the meantime the Home Guard companies of Lincoln, Uni - versity Place, College View, Havelock, and Ashland had been mobilized, a volunteer force of three hundred ex-service men of Lincoln was raised, all available arms collected and a special train was gotten ready and was standing on the track ready to move the aforementioned forces to Omaha when we were informed that the mob had accomplished its pur - pose and was dispersing. The estimated damage to the Douglas County Court House, caused by this riot, was approximately $1,000,000,00 in money and it leaves a blot on the fair name of the city of Omaha and the State of Nebraska, all of which would have been impossible with one battalion of National Guard located in the city and subject to the immediate call of 'the Gov - ernor as was evidenced by the tornado disaster in the city of Omaha, Easter Sunday, March 13, 1913, when with all telephone and telegraph wires down and the whole city in a demoralized condition, the Battalion of National Guard stationed in Omaha at that time was fully mobilized, moved to the scene of the disaster and in complete control of the situa - tion within two hours time. As compared with the above mentioned record of the National Guard at the tornado disaster is the fact that for the riot the first call for as - sistance was received about 6:30 in the evening and both telephone and telegraph were used in an effort to get the Federal troops located at Fort Crook and Fort Omaha, to move out at once but with the wires in per - fect working order and conditions away from the riot perfectly normal, it was after 11 o'clock before the desired order was finally received, thus demonstrating conclusively that we will never be able to depend upon Federal forces in case of local disorders. H. J. PAUL, The Adjutant General, Nebraska.

OFFICIAL: STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN December 3, 1920. General Orders, No. 5. The following schedule promulgated by Lieutenant Colonel W. A. Me-

12 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL Daniel, Inf., Inspector-Instructor for Nebraska, is hereby adopted and will be used by all Infantry organizations for the first six months train - in,? period after Federal recognition. By order of the Governor. H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. SCHEDULE OF ARMORY INSTRUCTIONS FOR FIRST SIX MONTHS 1. In compliance with Par. 486, National Guard Regulations, the fol - owing schedule of armory instruction for the first six months after federal recognition, is submitted in the order of importance of tha sub - ects. The Chronological order in which instruction in the various sub - ects is to be given should be regulated by local commanders, dependent upon weather conditions, facilities for drill, receipt of equipment, number f men present, instructors available and other circumstances: Total _ 36 Hrs. t2. Only the minimum time (36 hours) is included in the schedule, more time is utilized, it should be given to those subjects in which litional instruction is most urgent. bAny military instruction counts as "Drill," but the hour and a half aired, must be exclusive of "Rests". Time for rest and work can be t regulated by the commander giving the signals for simultaneous Subject. ] Hrs. Personal hygiene, first aid, and sanitation (including care of the feet and proper fitting of shoes and clothing) 3 Care and use of arms and equipment iy 2 Lectures on Riot Duty 1% Marching, night exercises and observing, learning and noting routes, and prominent places to be used or guarded in time of emergency 3 Preliminary drills for target practice 3 Assembling and disassembling equipment (including the "Pack", and marching in full equipment) i 6 Physical training 6 Guard duty 1 Close and extended order drill in the school of the soldier, squad, platoon and company : 11

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 13 resting and resumption of work and keeping record of the time. Daring - rest periods minute instructions should be given group leaders as to exactly what is to be done by each group during the next work period and no time should be lost. Instruction must be carried on energetically. k Recruits, inexperienced N. C. O.'s and specialists should be taught by ecially qualified instructors during such periods as the assembly of whole company is not required as a unit. Better results are obtained by short, "snappy" drills or lectures on different subjects rather than by straining the attention too long on one subject. Lecture meetings should be as informal as is consistent with liscipline, practical work being used instead of theoretical upon every possible occasion. Lectures, conferences and schools should never be teld immediately after a meal. Upon receiving the schedule of instruction the company commander should formulate definite plans for carrying out the schedule in the pro - gressive manner that will accomplish the best possible results. No hours have been set apart for the teaching of discipline, morale, C"litary courtesy and patriotism, as it is taken for granted that they will taught in conjunction with all other instruction. All officers and soldiers should realize that at no time in our history has discipline been so important; therefore discipline of the highest order should be exacted at all times. Leaders must insist that all subordinates do their work properly, but they must set the example themselves. Leaders must know their work. There must be no hesitation. Com - mands must be given correctly and with snap. Superiors must treat all subordinates with courtesy, .give clear and reasonable explanations, and correct mistakes without harshness. Every officer must set a proper example for those junior to him by promptly and cheerfully obeying - orders and regulations. Patriotism is of paramount importance. An absolute and unqualified devotion to the welfare and success of our country is an indispensible pre - requisite that has always constituted the soul of our Army. 3. The following are some of the reasons for attaching special im - portance to the subjects enumerated in the above schedule: (a) Hygience and sanitation: — Although tactical and destructive - superiority are most important in actual combat, yet the preparation for battle begins with the very first instruction of the recruit and without The proper fitting of shoes and clothing is of such extreme importance because of its effect upon the marching and working capacity of the wearers. Ill-fitting shoes and clothing not only incapacitate physically, good health and physique he will never reach the battle field.

14 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL but they lower the morale by causing discouragement, discontent and ill - temper. Tight collars, especially, cause headache, dizziness and other indispositions with consequent mental inefficiency. The actual tryng on and fitting of shoes and clothing must be under the personal supervision of the company commander and he must require the rules laid down in G. O. 26, W. D., Aug. 16, 1912, and other official documents to be observed regardless of individual protests. Left to :heir own discretion, men will almost invariably select shoes and clotti - ng much too tight. bA properly fitting shoe should have at least three-quarters of an inch ant space in front of the great toe and there should be no pressure in the top of the toes; to determine the proper width of shoe grasp the leather over the ball of the foot between the thumb and finger. As the fingers and thumb are brought slowly together over the leather, the shoe should feel snugly filled without apparent tension, while the leather should lie smoothly under the hand. If the leather wrinkles under the grasp of the hand, the shoe is too wide; if the leather seems tense and bulging and the thumb and fingers tend to slip over the leather easily, the shoe is too narrow. Socks should be two sizes larger than the shoes selected. Cotton socks are not allowed for marching, except in individual cases upon the prescription of the surgeon. Shoes are fitted with a 40-lb. weight upon the back and the whole weight of the body thrown upon the foot being fitted. In the fitting of clothing, allowance must be made for free movement at the knees, hips, chest, arms and neck. In trying on the coat an issue flannel shirt should be worn and the double thickness of collar folded between the coat and neck so as to show the shirt above the coat. (b) The best time for teaching the care and preservation of arms and equipment is about the time of their being issued to individuals. Officers and men should be required to receipt for all articles of equipment and clothing issued to them, in order that there will be no question concern - ing responsibility in case of loss or damage. Pistols and revolvers are especially apt to be lost or stolen. They should not be issued to indi - viduals until their use is absolutely required and the number should be ■verified after each drill. Whether in the hands of the organization or individuals they should be kept under lock and key when not in use. In this connection, attention is invited to Pars. 876, 885 and 886, National Guard Regulations; if the arm racks and lockers are not already on hand they should be obtained from the Ordnance Department by requisition. Because of the Government price of small arms being so much less than the commercial price, the paying for an article lost through carelessness

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 15 Or neglect is not sufficient restitution and an individual should be court - martialed and fined heavily if found guilty in order that the cost to him of an amount much greater than the price of the article may discourage future similar losses. The momentary value of a pistol is not so great as the seriousness of having this destructive deadly weapon in the hands of unknown evil persons. The number of Government weapons so unac - counted for at the present time is appalling. Most rifles turned in to arsenals as unserviceable are found to be worn at the muzzles and having the barrels rusted and pitted inside show - ing improper cleaning and lack of cleaning as having caused the damag - ed condition, whereas, with proper care rifles should become inaccurate only by reason of erosion at the bullet seat, usually after about 4,000 or 5,000 rounds have been fired. Inspection of arms should be made for the purpose of seeing that they are kept well oiled rather than to require the inside of the barrels to be bright and shining. Oil should be removed from the inside of the barrels only when it is to be renewed. There is no necessity for removing the original cosmoline from the inside of the barrel until firing is desired. While firing, cleaning of the inside of the barrel- should be thoroughly done every day under the supervision of competent instructors, the cleaning rod never to be inserted from the muzzle. When the firing is completed the barrels should again be filled with cosmoline, vaseline or other heavy oil and left oiled. Three-in-one and other light oils soon evaporate, leaving the steel exposed to attacks of rust. Web and leather equipment are usually injured by excessive washing and drying in the sun or near a fire, whereas, they should be dried in a cool place in the shade. Ordnance preparations should be obtained on requisition for all cleaning and preserving purposes. (c) Lectures on riot duty should be given at the earliest convenient opportunity as a riot or other emergency may occur unexpectedly. The lectures should be based on W. D. Document 882 and A Treatise on Riot Duty for the National Guard, by Col. Henry Bellow, recently adopted by the War Department and published in May of this year. (d) Marches and night exercises and exercises for the purpose of learning the location of all streets, roads, factories, public buildings, ad - vantageous positions, etc., can easily be combined by practicing the most suitable tactical formations on practice marches made at night, when the necessity for silence, absence of lights, and the difficulty of maintaining contact, communication and direction should be impressed upon every one engaged in the exercises. (e) As the bullet and bayonet are the principal weapons of Infantry, preliminary trainirvg for target practice should be started even before the rifles are received by the company, by conducting sighting drills with the

16 REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL sighting bar as prescribed in Par. 16, Small Arms Firing Manual. The secret of successful rifle firing is the proper co-ordination of the breath, eye and muscles in aiming, and the squeezing of the trigger in such a manner that the firer will not know just when the rifle will go off. The soldier's practice must be such as to make proper aiming and trigger squeeze a fixed habit, for only when such is the case will he do it pro - perly under stress of battle. Correct training in rapid loading is im - portant. Gallery practice should begin as soon as the men are far enough advanced. With thorough preliminary drills, men will have the foundation for good markmanship before beginning target practice. (f) Irksome though the making up, carrying and taking apart the full equipment may be, a man cannot be considered as having qualified as a soldier until he can assemble a near pack and carry his full field equipment throughout an average day's march of 15 miles. (,g) With the small amount of time available for physical drill, the correct habits of posture, locomotion and breathing; alertness of mind and body and the lossening of the muscles by setting up exercises should be tried for rather than the development of strength and endurance. The amount, scope and violence of physical drill should be gradually increased for beginners. (h) Although guard duty is of great importance when the occasion for its use arises, only the general principles should be attempted in ar - mory drill, the minute details being reserved for the period of field train - ing or for actual service. (i) Necessity compels military instruction to begin with the school of the soldier, squad, platoon and company (including the manual of arms) in order that groups of men may be converted into military units and that the wishes and commands of the leaders may be executed in unison and without misunderstanding and confusion. Also that there may be a uniformity of training throughout the Army. Except for this purpose and the disciplinary value of teaching men the habit of obedience to orders, both close and extended order are of less importance than the other subjects in the schedule. Most close order drill is for the purpose of teaching discipline rather than for the purpose of teaching men how to get about on the battle field. As it has been found that only thoroughly disciplined troops can carry out a modern attack where every step must be taken in accordance with a careful schedule, the minds and bodies must be trained to habits of precise, un - hesitating obedience to the will of the leader, so that in the stress of battle soldiers will obey without conscious effort, mechanically, auto - matically, as the easiest and most natural line of action. 4. After each drill or exercise the specific work for the next one

REPORT OF THE ADJUTANT GENERAL 17 should be announced, in order that the leaders may have time to prepare themselves, as it is hardly possible to properly conduct a drill or exercise without special forethought and preparation for that particular drill or exercise. An instructor must be prepared to impart his knowledge to his pupils in addition to knowing it himself. 5. The training of Infantry is based on the subjects covered in In - fantry Drill Regulations, Field Service Regulations, Manual for Non - commissioned Officers and Privates, Manual of Physical Training and in other documents issued from time to time by the War Department in accordance with developments in the Art of War. W. A. McDANIEL, STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN December 7, 1920. General Orders, No. 6. 1. General Orders No. 2, 1920, are hereby rescinded. BY ORDER OF THE GOVERNOR: H. J. Paul, The Adjutant General, Nebraska. OFFICIAL STATE OF NEBRASKA ADJUTANT GENERAL'S DEPARTMENT LINCOLN July 31, 1919. Special Orders, No. 1. 1.
